leopardInfo.title: Yala National Park
leopardInfo.location: Yala National Park, situated in the southeastern corner of Sri Lanka, is the country's most renowned wildlife sanctuary.
leopardInfo.habitat: The park boasts a diverse range of ecosystems, including dense forests, grasslands, and coastal areas, creating an ideal habitat for leopards.
leopardInfo.population: Yala National Park has one of the highest leopard densities in the world, providing visitors with a good chance of spotting these elusive big cats.
leopardInfo.bestTime: The dry season from February to July is considered the best time for leopard sightings when the animals gather near water sources.

leopardInfo.title: Wilpattu National Park
leopardInfo.location: Wilpattu National Park, located in the northwest of Sri Lanka, is the largest national park in the country.
leopardInfo.habitat: The park is characterized by dense scrublands, natural lakes (villus), and open grassy plains, creating an ideal environment for leopards to thrive.
leopardInfo.population: Wilpattu is home to a significant population of leopards, and its expansive landscapes provide both challenges and opportunities for leopard enthusiasts.
leopardInfo.bestTime: The dry season from June to September is recommended for wildlife safaris, offering better visibility and increased chances of leopard sightings.

leopardInfo.title: Udawalawe National Park
leopardInfo.location: Udawalawe National Park, situated in the southern part of Sri Lanka, is renowned for its large population of Asian elephants.
leopardInfo.habitat: The park features open grasslands and scrub forests, providing a contrasting environment for leopards compared to the more forested areas.
leopardInfo.population: While Udawalawe is not as famous for leopards as some other parks, sightings are still possible, and the park offers a unique landscape for observing these big cats.
leopardInfo.bestTime: Udawalawe is a year-round destination, and visitors have a good chance of spotting leopards during their exploration of the park.

threats.title: Habitat Loss and Fragmentation
threats.consequences: Deforestation and land development lead to the loss and fragmentation of the leopard's natural habitat, reducing available territories and prey.
threats.mitigation: Conservation efforts focus on preserving and restoring critical habitats, establishing protected areas, and implementing sustainable land-use practices.

threats.title: Human-Wildlife Conflict
threats.consequences: Encounters with humans often result in retaliatory killings, posing a direct threat to leopard populations.
threats.mitigation: Initiatives involve community education, the implementation of secure livestock enclosures, and the development of early-warning systems to reduce conflicts and promote coexistence.
